Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

To all the overbearing managers who stifle creativity and productivity, refusing to allow your team the freedom of flexible schedules limits their potential. When you impose rigid working hours, you often overlook the unique rhythms that each individual has in their work habits. Many employees thrive in environments where they can choose when to tackle tasks, leading to improved focus and quality of work. By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. When creativity and initiative are suppressed, the brightest minds may look for opportunities elsewhere, creating a challenging void to fill.This is a crucial topic, but I firmly believe that remote work reduces stress, boosts productivity, and sparks innovation. I thrive on a hybrid scheduleâ€”I enjoy the flexibility while relishing connecting with my coworkers in person! ğŸ«±ğŸ¼â€ğŸ«²ğŸ¼As Huyuni said, â€œWeâ€™re saving PDFs, not lives.â€ ğŸ’¼ğŸ’»

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

To all the overbearing managers who stifle creativity and productivity, refusing to allow your team the freedom of flexible schedules limits their potential. When you impose rigid working hours, you often overlook the unique rhythms that each individual has in their work habits. Many employees thrive in environments where they can choose when to tackle tasks, leading to improved focus and quality of work. By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. When creativity and initiative are suppressed, the brightest minds may look for opportunities elsewhere, creating a challenging void to fill.This is a crucial topic, but I firmly believe that remote work reduces stress, boosts productivity, and sparks innovation. Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

When you impose rigid working hours, you often overlook the unique rhythms that each individual has in their work habits. By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

When you impose rigid working hours, you often overlook the unique rhythms that each individual has in their work habits. By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

To all the overbearing managers who stifle creativity and productivity, refusing to allow your team the freedom of flexible schedules limits their potential. When you impose rigid working hours, you often overlook the unique rhythms that each individual has in their work habits. Many employees thrive in environments where they can choose when to tackle tasks, leading to improved focus and quality of work. By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. When creativity and initiative are suppressed, the brightest minds may look for opportunities elsewhere, creating a challenging void to fill.This is a crucial topic, but I firmly believe that remote work reduces stress, boosts productivity, and sparks innovation. Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

To all the overbearing managers who stifle creativity and productivity, refusing to allow your team the freedom of flexible schedules limits their potential. When you impose rigid working hours, you often overlook the unique rhythms that each individual has in their work habits. Many employees thrive in environments where they can choose when to tackle tasks, leading to improved focus and quality of work. By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. They just wanted to maintain control over the situation and limit remote work.Overshadowing a team's independence with relentless micromanagement can lead you down a fruitless path, ultimately risking the departure of your most valuable talent. When creativity and initiative are suppressed, the brightest minds may look for opportunities elsewhere, creating a challenging void to fill.This is a crucial topic, but I firmly believe that remote work reduces stress, boosts productivity, and sparks innovation. I thrive on a hybrid scheduleâ€”I enjoy the flexibility while relishing connecting with my coworkers in person! ğŸ«±ğŸ¼â€ğŸ«²ğŸ¼As Huyuni said, â€œWeâ€™re saving PDFs, not lives.â€ ğŸ’¼ğŸ’»

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

To all the overbearing managers who stifle creativity and productivity, refusing to allow your team the freedom of flexible schedules limits their potential. When you impose rigid working hours, you often overlook the unique rhythms that each individual has in their work habits. Many employees thrive in environments where they can choose when to tackle tasks, leading to improved focus and quality of work. By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. They just wanted to maintain control over the situation and limit remote work.Overshadowing a team's independence with relentless micromanagement can lead you down a fruitless path, ultimately risking the departure of your most valuable talent. When creativity and initiative are suppressed, the brightest minds may look for opportunities elsewhere, creating a challenging void to fill.This is a crucial topic, but I firmly believe that remote work reduces stress, boosts productivity, and sparks innovation. I thrive on a hybrid scheduleâ€”I enjoy the flexibility while relishing connecting with my coworkers in person! ğŸ«±ğŸ¼â€ğŸ«²ğŸ¼As Huyuni said, â€œWeâ€™re saving PDFs, not lives.â€ ğŸ’¼ğŸ’»

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

I studied Java at university and I have worked very little on Java projects in my work career, however I never liked its checked exception concept which forces every developer to manage or declare exceptions in every method making them unusable.Personally, I consider exceptions exceptional events which occur rarely (if the codebase is "sound") and which must be managed seldomly; most of the times exceptions have to propagate automatically up the call stack till top level exception handlers or even be left unmanaged and .NET/C++ works in this way.Looking at how a developer handles the exception is an easy way to spot if he is a Java man or not.hashtag#exception hashtag#management

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

I studied Java at university and I have worked very little on Java projects in my work career, however I never liked its checked exception concept which forces every developer to manage or declare exceptions in every method making them unusable.Personally, I consider exceptions exceptional events which occur rarely (if the codebase is "sound") and which must be managed seldomly; most of the times exceptions have to propagate automatically up the call stack till top level exception handlers or even be left unmanaged and .NET/C++ works in this way.Looking at how a developer handles the exception is an easy way to spot if he is a Java man or not.hashtag#exception hashtag#management

When you impose rigid working hours, you often overlook the unique rhythms that each individual has in their work habits. By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

I studied Java at university and I have worked very little on Java projects in my work career, however I never liked its checked exception concept which forces every developer to manage or declare exceptions in every method making them unusable.Personally, I consider exceptions exceptional events which occur rarely (if the codebase is "sound") and which must be managed seldomly; most of the times exceptions have to propagate automatically up the call stack till top level exception handlers or even be left unmanaged and .NET/C++ works in this way.Looking at how a developer handles the exception is an easy way to spot if he is a Java man or not.hashtag#exception hashtag#management

To all the overbearing managers who stifle creativity and productivity, refusing to allow your team the freedom of flexible schedules limits their potential. When you impose rigid working hours, you often overlook the unique rhythms that each individual has in their work habits. Many employees thrive in environments where they can choose when to tackle tasks, leading to improved focus and quality of work. By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. When creativity and initiative are suppressed, the brightest minds may look for opportunities elsewhere, creating a challenging void to fill.This is a crucial topic, but I firmly believe that remote work reduces stress, boosts productivity, and sparks innovation. I thrive on a hybrid scheduleâ€”I enjoy the flexibility while relishing connecting with my coworkers in person! ğŸ«±ğŸ¼â€ğŸ«²ğŸ¼As Huyuni said, â€œWeâ€™re saving PDFs, not lives.â€ ğŸ’¼ğŸ’»

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

I studied Java at university and I have worked very little on Java projects in my work career, however I never liked its checked exception concept which forces every developer to manage or declare exceptions in every method making them unusable.Personally, I consider exceptions exceptional events which occur rarely (if the codebase is "sound") and which must be managed seldomly; most of the times exceptions have to propagate automatically up the call stack till top level exception handlers or even be left unmanaged and .NET/C++ works in this way.Looking at how a developer handles the exception is an easy way to spot if he is a Java man or not.hashtag#exception hashtag#management

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

The latest report adds 36 new Lighthouses â€“ nearly half are in Asia (about 30% in China), 25% in Europe, 10% in North America, and the first one has just launched in Africa.What really stands out is that â€œworking smartâ€ isnâ€™t just about productivity. I studied Java at university and I have worked very little on Java projects in my work career, however I never liked its checked exception concept which forces every developer to manage or declare exceptions in every method making them unusable.Personally, I consider exceptions exceptional events which occur rarely (if the codebase is "sound") and which must be managed seldomly; most of the times exceptions have to propagate automatically up the call stack till top level exception handlers or even be left unmanaged and .NET/C++ works in this way.Looking at how a developer handles the exception is an easy way to spot if he is a Java man or not.hashtag#exception hashtag#management

To all the overbearing managers who stifle creativity and productivity, refusing to allow your team the freedom of flexible schedules limits their potential. When you impose rigid working hours, you often overlook the unique rhythms that each individual has in their work habits. Many employees thrive in environments where they can choose when to tackle tasks, leading to improved focus and quality of work. By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. They just wanted to maintain control over the situation and limit remote work.Overshadowing a team's independence with relentless micromanagement can lead you down a fruitless path, ultimately risking the departure of your most valuable talent. When creativity and initiative are suppressed, the brightest minds may look for opportunities elsewhere, creating a challenging void to fill.This is a crucial topic, but I firmly believe that remote work reduces stress, boosts productivity, and sparks innovation. I thrive on a hybrid scheduleâ€”I enjoy the flexibility while relishing connecting with my coworkers in person! ğŸ«±ğŸ¼â€ğŸ«²ğŸ¼As Huyuni said, â€œWeâ€™re saving PDFs, not lives.â€ ğŸ’¼ğŸ’»

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

I studied Java at university and I have worked very little on Java projects in my work career, however I never liked its checked exception concept which forces every developer to manage or declare exceptions in every method making them unusable.Personally, I consider exceptions exceptional events which occur rarely (if the codebase is "sound") and which must be managed seldomly; most of the times exceptions have to propagate automatically up the call stack till top level exception handlers or even be left unmanaged and .NET/C++ works in this way.Looking at how a developer handles the exception is an easy way to spot if he is a Java man or not.hashtag#exception hashtag#management

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

I studied Java at university and I have worked very little on Java projects in my work career, however I never liked its checked exception concept which forces every developer to manage or declare exceptions in every method making them unusable.Personally, I consider exceptions exceptional events which occur rarely (if the codebase is "sound") and which must be managed seldomly; most of the times exceptions have to propagate automatically up the call stack till top level exception handlers or even be left unmanaged and .NET/C++ works in this way.Looking at how a developer handles the exception is an easy way to spot if he is a Java man or not.hashtag#exception hashtag#management

ğŸš€ hashtag#Day51 of Learning Java! ğŸš€Super excited to share today's learnings about Inter-Thread Communication in Java! ğŸ¤ğŸ’¡ğŸ”„ 1. Inter-Thread Communication:Threads can communicate with each other using wait(), notify(), and notifyAll() methods.ğŸ”¹ wait() method:A thread that expects an update calls wait() and enters a waiting state until it gets notified.ğŸ”¹ notify() method:The thread responsible for updating calls notify(), which wakes up the waiting thread so it can proceed with updated data.ğŸ”¹ Locking Condition:A thread must hold the object's lock (i.e., be inside a synchronized block) to call wait(), notify(), or notifyAll().âš ï¸ 2. IllegalMonitorStateException:If we call wait(), notify(), or notifyAll() outside a Synchronized Block or Method, we get a runtime exception:IllegalMonitorStateException ğŸš¨â“ 3. Why Are These Methods in Object Class & Not in Thread Class?Unlike start(), join(), and sleep(), which belong to Thread class, these methods are in Object class because they can be called on any Java object, not just threads.ğŸ“ Example: Just like messages can be delivered by a postman, teacher, or student, inter-thread communication methods can be used on any object! ğŸ“©ğŸ“ğŸ–Š 4. Method Declarations:âœ… wait() Methods:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»public final void wait() throws InterruptedException ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»public final native void wait(long ms) throws InterruptedException ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»public final void wait(long ms, int ns) throws InterruptedExceptionâœ… notify() Method:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»public final native void notify()âœ… notifyAll() Method:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»public final native void notifyAll()hashtag#Java hashtag#Multithreading hashtag#Learning hashtag#Coding hashtag#InterThreadCommunication  hashtag#Durgasoft hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment

To all the overbearing managers who stifle creativity and productivity, refusing to allow your team the freedom of flexible schedules limits their potential. When you impose rigid working hours, you often overlook the unique rhythms that each individual has in their work habits. Many employees thrive in environments where they can choose when to tackle tasks, leading to improved focus and quality of work. By granting your team the autonomy to manage their schedules, you foster trust and empowerment, ultimately enhancing overall performance and job satisfaction.ğŸ’«I once asked a manager why we couldnâ€™t be remote anymore like another department, and they responded that our work is more detailed than theirs, implying our tasks were more important. ğŸ™„However, at my job, we value every role equally. They just wanted to maintain control over the situation and limit remote work.Overshadowing a team's independence with relentless micromanagement can lead you down a fruitless path, ultimately risking the departure of your most valuable talent. When creativity and initiative are suppressed, the brightest minds may look for opportunities elsewhere, creating a challenging void to fill.This is a crucial topic, but I firmly believe that remote work reduces stress, boosts productivity, and sparks innovation. I thrive on a hybrid scheduleâ€”I enjoy the flexibility while relishing connecting with my coworkers in person! ğŸ«±ğŸ¼â€ğŸ«²ğŸ¼As Huyuni said, â€œWeâ€™re saving PDFs, not lives.â€ ğŸ’¼ğŸ’»

Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

I studied Java at university and I have worked very little on Java projects in my work career, however I never liked its checked exception concept which forces every developer to manage or declare exceptions in every method making them unusable.Personally, I consider exceptions exceptional events which occur rarely (if the codebase is "sound") and which must be managed seldomly; most of the times exceptions have to propagate automatically up the call stack till top level exception handlers or even be left unmanaged and .NET/C++ works in this way.Looking at how a developer handles the exception is an easy way to spot if he is a Java man or not.hashtag#exception hashtag#management

ğŸš€ hashtag#Day51 of Learning Java! ğŸš€Super excited to share today's learnings about Inter-Thread Communication in Java! ğŸ¤ğŸ’¡ğŸ”„ 1. Inter-Thread Communication:Threads can communicate with each other using wait(), notify(), and notifyAll() methods.ğŸ”¹ wait() method:A thread that expects an update calls wait() and enters a waiting state until it gets notified.ğŸ”¹ notify() method:The thread responsible for updating calls notify(), which wakes up the waiting thread so it can proceed with updated data.ğŸ”¹ Locking Condition:A thread must hold the object's lock (i.e., be inside a synchronized block) to call wait(), notify(), or notifyAll().âš ï¸ 2. IllegalMonitorStateException:If we call wait(), notify(), or notifyAll() outside a Synchronized Block or Method, we get a runtime exception:IllegalMonitorStateException ğŸš¨â“ 3. Why Are These Methods in Object Class & Not in Thread Class?Unlike start(), join(), and sleep(), which belong to Thread class, these methods are in Object class because they can be called on any Java object, not just threads.ğŸ“ Example: Just like messages can be delivered by a postman, teacher, or student, inter-thread communication methods can be used on any object! ğŸ“©ğŸ“ğŸ–Š 4. Want to understand how G1GC works and why it replaced CMS GC?The G1 (Garbage First) Garbage Collector was introduced as an evolution of CMS, designed to deliver low latency, high throughput, and reduced memory fragmentation. Unlike traditional collectors, G1GC divides the heap into dynamic regions instead of fixed generations, allowing better allocation and collection efficiency.When should you consider using it? - Applications that require predictable garbage collection pauses. - Systems with large heaps that need efficient memory management. - Workloads where latency and performance balance is critical.The downside? - Requires fine-tuning to achieve optimal performance. - More complex configuration compared to default collectors.Fun fact: - G1GC became the default GC in Java 9, replacing CMS and offering automatic memory compaction to avoid fragmentation issues.Want to try it?  - Add this JVM option: -XX:+UseG1GCWant to dive deeper into Java Garbage Collectors? Link in the comments!hashtag#Java hashtag#GarbageCollection hashtag#JVM hashtag#PerformanceOptimization hashtag#JavaDevelopment

I studied Java at university and I have worked very little on Java projects in my work career, however I never liked its checked exception concept which forces every developer to manage or declare exceptions in every method making them unusable.Personally, I consider exceptions exceptional events which occur rarely (if the codebase is "sound") and which must be managed seldomly; most of the times exceptions have to propagate automatically up the call stack till top level exception handlers or even be left unmanaged and .NET/C++ works in this way.Looking at how a developer handles the exception is an easy way to spot if he is a Java man or not.hashtag#exception hashtag#management

ğŸš€ hashtag#Day51 of Learning Java! ğŸš€Super excited to share today's learnings about Inter-Thread Communication in Java! ğŸ¤ğŸ’¡ğŸ”„ 1. Inter-Thread Communication:Threads can communicate with each other using wait(), notify(), and notifyAll() methods.ğŸ”¹ wait() method:A thread that expects an update calls wait() and enters a waiting state until it gets notified.ğŸ”¹ notify() method:The thread responsible for updating calls notify(), which wakes up the waiting thread so it can proceed with updated data.ğŸ”¹ Locking Condition:A thread must hold the object's lock (i.e., be inside a synchronized block) to call wait(), notify(), or notifyAll().âš ï¸ 2. IllegalMonitorStateException:If we call wait(), notify(), or notifyAll() outside a Synchronized Block or Method, we get a runtime exception:IllegalMonitorStateException ğŸš¨â“ 3. Why Are These Methods in Object Class & Not in Thread Class?Unlike start(), join(), and sleep(), which belong to Thread class, these methods are in Object class because they can be called on any Java object, not just threads.ğŸ“ Example: Just like messages can be delivered by a postman, teacher, or student, inter-thread communication methods can be used on any object! ğŸ“©ğŸ“ğŸ–Š 4. Method Declarations:âœ… wait() Methods:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»public final void wait() throws InterruptedException ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»public final native void wait(long ms) throws InterruptedException ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»public final void wait(long ms, int ns) throws InterruptedExceptionâœ… notify() Method:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»public final native void notify()âœ… notifyAll() Method:ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»public final native void notifyAll()hashtag#Java hashtag#Multithreading hashtag#Learning hashtag#Coding hashtag#InterThreadCommunication  hashtag#Durgasoft hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment
